title: How to Manage Lower Back Pain
author: Candina Jordan

content: Ankylosing spondylitis (AS) causes the joints and ligaments that normally allow your spine to move freely to become inflamed and stiff. Since it's a condition that mostly affects your back, lower back pain is one of the primary symptoms. Often, the biggest challenge for people with AS is managing this lower back pain. Although there is no cure, there are several options available for dealing with the chronic back associated with AS.

content_blocks.text: Ankylosing spondylitis (AS) causes the joints and ligaments that normally allow your spine to move freely to become inflamed and stiff. Since it's a condition that mostly affects your back, lower back pain is one of the primary symptoms. Often, the biggest challenge for people with AS is managing this lower back pain. Although there is no cure, there are several options available for dealing with the chronic back associated with AS.

sections.heading: Physical Therapy and Exercise
content: Exercise will help strengthen your back and neck muscles so you can maintain good posture. Stretching exercises can help you maintain your flexibility and range of motion.  Your physical therapist will help design an exercise program that is tailored to your needs. Since AS can affect your breathing, you'll probably need to incorporate deep breathing and aerobic exercises as well. Physical therapy may not stop your AS from getting worse, but it may help relieve your symptoms.

sections.heading: Anti-Inflammatory Diet
content: Diets that are high in foods that cause inflammation, such as trans fats, processed foods, and refined sugar, can make arthritis pain worse. Eating foods that have antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and analgesic properties may help ease your pain. The following foods are high in these properties:
bullets: Fish that are high in omega-3s such as salmon , tuna, and sardines

content_blocks.text: Diets that are high in foods that cause inflammation, such as trans fats, processed foods, and refined sugar, can make arthritis pain worse. Eating foods that have antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and analgesic properties may help ease your pain. The following foods are high in these properties:
associated_bullets: Fish that are high in omega-3s such as salmon , tuna, and sardines

sections.heading: Hot or Cold Therapy
content: Hot or cold therapy may both be effective for relieving back pain. Heat loosens up your muscles and increases your flexibility, while cold can numb the pain. You can try both to see what works best. Some people find that heat works better before exercising and cold works better afterward.

Try soaking in a warm bath or taking a hot shower for 20 minutes. You can wear warm clothes afterward to help hold in the heat. A heating pad or moist heat pads can be applied to sore areas. You can make your own by microwaving a damp towel. Check to make sure it isn't too hot and then wrap it in a dry towel before applying.
You can apply an ice pack for 20 minutes at a time for cold therapy. You can use gel-filled cold packs, frozen peas, or ice cubes in a freezer bag.

meta_description: Learn how you can manage nausea with physical therapy, diet, and heat or cold therapy.
